xs:annotation.xs:documentation: Root element of the Intrinsic Disorder Format

Describes one or more structural states of one or more regions as a self-contained unit. Multiple entries from different files can be concatenated into a single entrySet. Grouping within an entry will likely be based on publication or protein.
PSI ID level
PSI ID version within given level
Desciption of the source of the entry, usually a database that holds the entry, but also a submitting organisation, group, experimentalist, or consortium
Name(s) of the data source.
Bibliographic reference for the data source, for example a paper which describes all structure states of the entry.

Unambiguous identification of the source by a CV term; for instance, the primary reference with attributes db="psi-mi" dbAc="MI:0488" id="MI:1332" refType= "identity" refTypeAc="MI:0356" refers to source bhf-ucl, which is identical to term MI:1332 in PSI-MI CV, which lists itself as term MI:0488. For this we need to define similar PSI-ID CV terms.
Further description of the source.
Data availability statements, for example copyrights
Describes data availability, e.g. through a copyright statement. If no availability is given, the data is assumed to be freely available.
A text describing the availability of data, e.g. a copyright statement.
All experiments in which the structure states of this entry have been determined
Describes one set of experimental parameters, usually associated with a single publication.
List of experiments in which this structure has been determined.
Either refer to an already defined experiment in this entry or insert description.
References an experiment already present in this entry.
Fully describe an experiment in which this structure has been determined.
Describes one set of experimental parameters.
Publication describing the experiment.
Refers to external database description of the experiment.
Experimental method to identify the molecule from which the analysed region(s) is derived. This element is controlled by the ECO controlled vocabulary.

Experimental method to determine the features of experimental constructs. If this element is filled it is assumed to apply to all features described in the experiment, but it can be overridden by the featureDetectionMethod given in the individual feature. This element is controlled by the ECO controlled vocabulary.
A list of (variable) parameters used in this experiment, eg temperature.
Semi-structured additional description of the experiment.
All major objects have a numerical id which must be unique to that object within an entry. The object may be repeated, though, e.g. in the denormalised representation.
List of all molecules occurring in the entry, i.e. all molecules from which regions analysed in the entry are derived
A molecule object in its native state, as described in databases.
Usage: A protein must contain an xref to UniProt and NCBI-GI where possible.
Describes a molecule.
Name(s). The short label is typically a short name that could appear as a label on a diagram.
A molecule should have an xref whenever possible. If the molecule is not available in external databases, it must be characterised within this object e.g. by its sequence.
The normal source organism of the molecule.
Sequence in uppercase
Usage:
Allows semi-structured additional annotation of the molecule.
All major objects have a numerical id which is unique to that object within a PSI ID file. The object may be repeated, though, e.g. in the denormalised representation.
The experimental region/construct for which the structure was determined.
The name(s) of the analysed region given by the authors of a publication.
The xref(s) for the region given by the authors of a publication.

Location of the feature on the sequence of the molecule described in an external resource. One feature may have more than one featureRange, used e.g. for features which involve sequence positions close in the folded, three-dimensional state of a protein, but non-continuous along the sequence.
Sequence in uppercase
Usage:
Description of the source molecule of the region. Refers to an already defined molecule in this entry (in moleculeList, for compact form), or fully describes a source molecule.
References a source molecule described in the moleculeList of the entry (for compact form).
Fully describes a source molecule (in expanded form).
Semi-structured additional description of the data contained in the entry.
Sequence features relevant for the structure state of the region, such as PTM, or for instance experimental modifications, e.g. protein tags.
A feature on a sequence, or any modifications made to the source sequence.
Names for the feature.
Reference to an external description of the feature.
Description and classification of the feature. This element is controlled by the PSI-MI controlled vocabulary "feature", root term id MI:0116.
Experimental method used to identify the feature. A setting here overrides the global setting given in the experimentDescription. This element is controlled by he ECO controlled vocabulary.

Location of the feature on the sequence of the molecule described in an external resource. One feature may have more than one featureRange, used e.g. for features which involve sequence positions close in the folded, three-dimensional state of a protein, but non-continuous along the sequence.
Semi-structured additional description of the data contained in the entry.
List of experimentally determined structure states of region(s)
Description of the structure state of one or more regions of an experimental construct as determined by one experimental method described in a publication
A structure state of one experimental construct described with some experimental context. Different regions having a different structural state can be defined for one experimental construct.
Name(s) of the structure state.
Reference to an external resource describing this structure state for this region as determined by this experiment
Either refer to an already defined availability statement in this entry (compact) or insert availability description (expanded).
References an availability statement already present in this entry.
Describes the availability of the structural data. If no availability is given, the data is assumed to be freely available.
Description of the tested region, ie the construct that was used in the experiment.
List of structural states observed for different regions of the tested construct.
A list of variable/dynamic parameters used in this experiment to investigate dynamic structure states.
All major objects have a numerical id which is unique to that object within a PSI ID file. The object may be repeated, though, e.g. in the denormalised representation.
List of one or more structural states observed for one or more regions of the experimental construct.
A structural state observed for one or more regions of an experimenta; construct.
Reference to an external resource describing this structure state for this region as determined by this experiment
External controlled vocabulary (IDPO) characterising the structure state type, currently with binary classification "ordered" and "intrinsically disordered".
Definition of the region of the tested construct for which the described structure state applies.
Sequence in uppercase
Usage:
Semi-structured additional description of the data contained in the entry.
A list of (variable) parameters used in this experiment, eg (variable) temperature.
Describes one (variable parameter) and its value(s) in this experiment, eg temperature.
Free description of the (variable parameter).
Unit of the (variable) parameter value(s).
List of the (different) value(s) for this specific variableParameter in this experiment.
List of the (different) value(s) for a specific variableParameter in a specific experiment.
A value for a specific variableParameter in a specific experiment, eg temperature.
Free description of the variable value. It can be numerical value or qualitative value depending on the variableParameter.
Unique numerical identifier for this variableValue so a structure state can refer to it later. The id has to be unique within a same entry.
Optional numerical order attribute to give an explicit order for a variableValue in the variableValueList.
A list of experimental parameter/condition values for which the structure state is observed.
A set of experimental parameter/conditions values applied together and for which this structure state is observed.
A set of experimental parameter/conditions values applied together and for which this structure state is observed.
The reference to the id of the variableValue described in the variableParameterList/variableParameter/variableParameterValueList of the experiment.
Reference to an external controlled vocabulary.
Name of the controlled vocabulary term.
Source of the controlled vocabulary term. E.g. the name of the CV and the term ID.
Allows to reference an external controlled vocabulary, or to directly include a value if no suitable external definition is available.
This contains the controlled vocabulary terms, as a short and optionally as a long form.
Refers to the term of the controlled vocabulary in an external database.

If no suitable external controlled vocabulary is available, this attributeList can be used to describe the term. Example: Attribute name: Mouse atlas tissue name; attribute value: spinal cord, day 30.
Names for an object.
A short string, suitable to remember the object. Can be e.g. a protein name, the first author of a paper, etc.
A full, detailed name or description of the object. Can be e.g. the full title of a publication, or the scientific name of a species.
A short alphanumeric label identifying an object. Not necessarily unique.
Full, descriptive object name.
Describes the biological source of an object, in simple form only the NCBI taxid.
The names of the organism. The short label should be a common name if it exists. The full name should be the full name of the species (i.e. genus species).
Description of the cell type. Currently no species-independent controlled vocabulary for cell types is available, therefore the choice of reference database(s) is open to the data provider.
The subcellular compartment of the object. It is strongly recommended to refer to the Gene Ontology cellular component in this element.
Description of the source tissue. Currently no species-independent controlled vocabulary for tissues is available, therefore the choice of reference database(s) is open to the data provider.
The host organism(s) in which the experiment has been performed.
Bibliographic reference.
Bibliographic reference in external database, usually PubMed.
Additional description of bibliographic reference such as publication title, authors, journal, publication date...
Alternative description of bibliographic reference if no external database entry is available.
Crossreference to an external database. Crossreferences to literature databases, e.g. PubMed, should not be put into this structure, but into the bibRef element where possible.
Primary reference to an external database.
Further external objects describing the object.
Refers to a unique object in an external database, eg a protein in UniProt or an entry in DisProt.
Name of the external database, taken from the controlled vocabulary of databases.
Accession number of the database in the database CV. This element is controlled by the PSI-MI CV "database citation", root term id MI:0444.
Primary identifier of the object in the external database, e.g. UniProt accession number.
Secondary identifier of the object in the external database, e.g. UniProt ID.
The version number of the object in the external database.

Reference type, e.g. "identity" if this reference refers to an identical object in the external database, or "see-also" for additional information, using a term from PSI-MI CV, root term cross-reference type (MI:0353).
Reference type accession number from the CV of reference types. This element is controlled by the PSI-MI CV "xref type", root term id MI:0353.
Refers to a list of experiments within the same entry.
References an experiment already present in this entry.
The method(s) by which this experimental construct has been determined. If this element is present, its value supersedes experimentDescription/moleculeIdentificationMethod.
Experimental method to determine the experimental construct analysed in the experiment. This element is controlled by the ECO controlled vocabulary.
If no experimentRef is given, it is assumed this refers to all experiments linked to the structure state.
Terms describing the experimental preparation of studied regions.
A location on a sequence. Both begin and end can be a defined position, a fuzzy position, or undetermined.
Attribute of the start positions, e.g. "certain" or "n-terminal"

The integer position gives the begin position of the feature. The first base or amino acid is position 1. In combination with the numeric value, the attribute 'status' allows to express fuzzy positions, e.g. 'less than 4'. Negative positions can be used to describe promotor regions but should not be allowed for proteins

The begin position may be varying or unclear, but localisable to a certain range. Usually written as e.g. 3..5. Negative positions can be used to describe promotor regions but should not be allowed for proteins
Attribute of the end positions, e.g. "certain" or "c-terminal"

The integer position gives the end position of the feature. The first base or amino acid is position 1. In combination with the numeric value, the attribute 'status' allows to express fuzzy positions, e.g. 'more than 400'. Negative positions can be used to describe promotor regions but should not be allowed for proteins

The end position may be varying or unclear, but localisable to a certain range. Usually written as e.g. 3..5. Negative positions can be used to describe promotor regions but should not be allowed for proteins

True if the described feature is a linking feature connecting two amino acids rather than extending along the sequence. 'begin' references the first amino acid, 'end' the second. Standard example is a disulfide bridge. Does not reference another feature, therefore is only suitable for linking features on the same amino acid chain.
An interval on a sequence.
A list of additional attributes. Open tag-value list to allow the inclusion of additional data.
The name of the attribute, taken from CV.
Enables control of the attribute type through reference to an external controlled vocabulary.
